values:
you read it right. this is going to be my last post on live journal. haha, who would've thought, huh? it took me a week to decide whether or not to go through with it, but then i thought it's high time that this phase of my life found its finish. lj has served me well for the past two-and- a-half years, and after browsing through all my entries, and i guess i learned a few things along the way: * traveling gives you new points of view -- literally and figuratively. * everything happens for a reason. * life answers all the questions you throw at it -- in one way or another. * it always pays to have faith. * when you think the world has abandoned you, somebody suddenly pops out of the woodwork and proves you wrong. * the world is so beautiful to see that it would such a pity to be blinded by sadness and cynicism. * experience is the best teacher, and sometimes, mistakes are the best lessons. * there are always two sides on a coin, a silver linning behind every cloud, and a pot of gold at the end of every rainbow. * you can always choose to be happy. * wearing high heels is empowering. (now where did that come from?) * you're different from the person you are yesterday; there is always the chance to change. * when things get rough, it's not about having the strength to move on -- it's about having the will to try. it's nice to think that though i've been through the highest of highs and the lowest of lows, it's all been good. life's been good. and i am thankful for that and for all the people who made it possible. (okay, i am trying very hard not to be dramatic about this.) so, where will charlene be after this? oh, this journal will still have a week or so before it final closes down. i've got to save a lot of things, after all. when that's done, i might still be on the net, somewhere else. ^_^ as you probably know, it's kinda hard for me to stay put in one place for a very long time, but i'll be around. ^_^ well... well. i guess that's it. the end of my set. the last chord of the last song. now let me take my bow.
everybody, thanks for watching. i hope you enjoyed the show. it's been good, folks. it's been real good.

"eh alam mo naman pala eh. ba't banat ka pa ng banat?" "banat? ...masama bang umasa?"
oooh... kitakits days hahaha. anyway, thanks to those who greeted me on my birthday. ^_^ spent it quietly, and i realized that hey, quiet is pretty cool. i got lots of hugs too, but the best part was the last text i got that day -- als, thanks so much! you made me so very happy. ^_^ my birthday resolution? oh i don't know. i'll just keep on riding this roller-coaster of a life i guess. not knowing what's gonna happen next is lotsa fun. and guess what? i got that good vibe again. you know that feeling when you can sense that something good's gonna happen? i'm getting that feeling as of late. last time i had that was before wendi's wedding. i dunno. i guess things are looking up. que sera sera. whatever will be, will be. (a more substantial post next time.)

...still, you wonder what all of this means, where all of this ends. sometimes, you feel it creeping from behind, and then you just stop walking. you stand right in the middle of the sidewalk and look up. where the hell am i? you hate pauses -- they make you think. so you quickly pick up the pace again lest you start wondering even more. you don't exactly have any problems, but somehow, you feel tired and disoriented, like something invisible is wearing you out. whatever it is, you constantly try to shake it off, and though at times you succeed, it always comes back with a vengeance. why am i here? the only thing you know is that you are perpetually teetering on the edge of something. though you live for today, you always hold your breath for what is yet to come. at times, you drink a bottle or two of something remotely alcoholic just enough to soften the world's edges that you constantly see. it works, but you know it's only until the effect wears out. what am i looking for? no, you aren't really lonely -- you're just not so happy. you don't know why but you feel that something is missing. you can't describe what it is, but you've recognized it during the times when you lie between sleep and waking. it's something that has always eluded you, and after a pretty long time, you're understandably tired of being eluded. what? then again maybe you're just thinking too much. you shrug and laugh the whole thing off. oh yes, you need a vacation. you miss the beach. the last time you were on the beach was the year's happiest week for you. you miss the feel of the sea breeze. spreading your arms and feeling it thread through you -- that was the closest thing you could get to flying.

first and foremost --
h a p p y b i r t h d a y ! kokoy mama andrew tita tetch sara janelle anne tina mia sheesha cayo chad
here's to november people! ^_^
* * *
mike and wendi's wedding held last october 21, it had got to be one of the simplest, sweetest, and most solemn events ever...
...and it was lotsa lotsa fun too!
congrats, you guys!
* * *
 lenor's wedding it's CFAD week in UST and my sister is part of a parade. ^_^ this year's theme revolves around dreams and fantasies. so cheryl's block decided to go macabre and went on giving edgar allan poe's lenor her dream wedding. guess who played lenor? ;p
they were SO adorable i kept on asking them to pose for me! i wanted to pull them to the main building but since they were still parading, i really couldn't. so i just blurred the background since i didn't like it all that much. cheryl more or less did her dress. apparently she was sewing 'til the wee hours of the morning. i just hafta hand it to her -- it came out pretty well. here's the entourage!
CUTENESS~! i honestly wanted to put them in my pocket and take them home. ^_^ of course, i also had me a little bit of fun. i LOVED the biomen~!
red one and pink five are gay, by the way. there was a dancing teletubby. i have it on video. it's kinda disturbing. @_@ next event: paskuhan.
* * *
okay, who's getting married next? ;p

lunchmates I was going through my picture files thinking that I should have everything printed soon when I came across this:
This was taken during Ala's despedida early this year. Yup -- the lunchmates haha! Though the shot's missing a few people, it still made me stare for a pretty long time until I got hit by one of those senti moments. I practically grew up with this people!

I remember Art Club sessions with Pam in '96. I remember Elea asking me to draw her a Sailormoon poster back in '94. I remember asking that Superlemon candy from Ala more than a decade ago. I miss these people a HELL lot. I saw Pam recently; I think that was shortly after the week I got sick (yup, I still had the mask on). We had lunch in Chocolate Kiss and then we waited for a wedding in the Bahay ng Alumni, all the while taking pictures. As for Elea, last I heard she was having weekday gigs in Makati. (I really ought to drop by and watch her; I bet she's really good...) Ala's in Australia, and every time I pass by Loyola Heights I miss that secure feeling of knowing that she would always be there in that old, warm house along B. Gonzales street. And yeah, thinking about all that made me cry a little. :p

* * *
updates (a.k.a. where the hell has charlene owen been?) It's been a full and hectic past few months! I was sick for the most part of August, and I spent the first three weeks of September recuperating. I still get coughing spells and sometimes breathing can be a bit of a chore, but I got medicine for that, and those instances are becoming rare. ^_^ And good thing they are, since October spells San Miguel Octoberfest and that means lotsa-lotsa party!

The opening was supposed to be held last Sept. 29 in the Megastrip, but it didn't push through because of the typhoon and the power outage. They moved it to Oct. 4, which was last Wednesday, and after doing overtime 'til 8, my officemate Sara and I decided to check it out. April called me up earlier on and we decided to meet up. All in all there were six of us -- April was with her friends. There were too many people though, so we ended up in having a few beers in Shang. It turned out to be a good idea since it rained pretty hard later that evening.

Actually, if it weren't for these impromptu after-work gimmicks, I would've hit my head on a wall a long time ago. It's almost the end of the year and after the lull months of the second quarter we're running after seasons in the office; the day the storm came and they suspended work I was at home doing 1,000 handmade Christmas tags. It wasn't that hard, but it was really time-consuming. And then there was planning to do for all the cards for next year's seasons -- I spent most of the past month's Saturdays in the office. Well at least, overtime means extra income, hehe. ButbutBUT, it isn't all that sad. After all, there's Wendi's WEDDING to attend! I'm already having the gown made based on the color and design scheme of the other sponsors -- it's this pink two-piece thing with an obi of deep coppery brown and organza. I'm SO excited, but at the same time freaked out. I've been helping the bride out with the arrangements, and wak, I'm gonna be playing during the reception! With a singer! And a pianist! And a saxophone player! I've never done that before! I was in UP the whole day today practicing with my teacher. Ignorant little me never realized how entirely different classical guitar was from jazz. The wedding is in two weeks by the way. Yikes. Pray for me.

* * *
things to look forward to - The wedding. The wedding the wedding the wedding! More than playing during the reception, I have this feeling that something else, something good is gonna happen. ^_^ - Come end of October, I'll hopefully be out of town again. GAD I hope it pushes through! I SO need a vacation. - My relatives are coming home for Christmas! - I'll be getting myself a bike before December ends. Yup. That I will. - Next year, if all goes well, I'll be heading to the States. - And tomorrow... well, tomorrow's a new day. That's enough to make me look forward to it. :p

i want to thank the people who replied to my text about my friend's brother nichi.  he's out of the ICU now, but we're still helping them out with the payments and the medicines.

any help will still be appreciated.

RULES: 1. Emphasize all lines that apply to you. 2. Tag five more people after you finish, complete with links to their sites. 3. Let the person you've tagged KNOW that they've been tagged, for Pete's sake. I wish I was a different ethnicity. I have an eating disorder. I'm short. I'm tall. I think I'm really attractive. Pwede bang i-mantra to? Sana gumanda ako... Sana mawala ang pimples ko... I prefer winter over summer. I'm a geek. Yes I am. Startrek, anyone? I'm a shopaholic. ESPECIALLY WHEN I'M DEPRESSED. Ask my friends about this. They know. I'm reasonably intelligent. I would like to think so. I'm attracted to girls. I'm attracted to boys. -- Not boys. Men. Woot~! I like British accents. I get goosebumps when Jude Law says "bloody". I smoke regularly. I drink regularly. I smoke socially. I drink socially. Well, recently I drink when I'm alone too. Gives me a goodnight's sleep. :) I get drunk easily. Gad, I have horror stories of this... I do drugs. I will never date a bad kisser. Whoopsie. I've lied to avoid kissing them again. I brush my hair at least 50 times a night. I'm religious. I'm not religious but have morals. Binky, ibaba mo ang kilay mo! I lie frequently. I'm impulsive. Very much so, and this has gotten me into a lot of trouble. I'm hardworking. Try working in my company, folks. I liked "Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind." I would wanna watch it. "She's All That" is one of my favourite movies. I'm good at History. I never got an A, but that's what I do now for part-time -- write and research. The 1800's is such an interesting era... I speak more than two languages. Tagalog, English, a bit of Japanese! Hehe, ang daya! I enjoy taking pictures. Very much so! I like spending money on myself. YES. I like spending money on others. Only on people I love, though. --> pareho tayo anne! I have a regular income. Thank God. I earn money on a job-by-job basis. I pay my own bills. I rely on my parents for money. Sometimes. I can cook. I'm no good though. I think I can bake better. I enjoy cleaning. Especially when I'm in a bad mood. Tidyness is a must in my life. I like clutter. You know the organized kind of clutter? :D My idea of good music is Britney Spears. I have heard of Blonde Redhead. I enjoy Blonde Redhead. I'm fashion-conscious. I have good taste. For really good food, hehe. People tell me I have good taste. Actually, my dad said I've got expensive taste. Which isn't really a good thing. I'm told I have yet to fulfill my potential. I'm good at sports. I'm good at certain sports. I couldn't do sports to save my life. Er... how about weight lifting and running on the treadmill? I'm artistically inclined. I like drawing. :) I wanna be an artist when I grow up. I wanna be an engineer when I grow up. I eat when I'm upset. I cannot adapt to change. I'm interested in politics. I have shoplifted. A couple of grapes from Supersale back when I was a wee kid. Hey, I was NINE. And I was HUNGRY. I download MP3s. I've done underage drinking. I think I had my first taste of beer at around 10... I've gone underage clubbing. I can dance reasonably well. Took up ballet. I can dance extremely well. I dance like a cardboard gorilla. I can sing. A little. I guess. I sing like someone stepped on my foot. I can swim. I enjoy surveys. I keep a journal. There's one that I write on almost every night. My teachers don't like me. I enjoy controversy. I can be a bitch/bastard. Only when provoked. I have a thing for bad boys/girls. I have tattoos. I've been in a nudist colony. I'm not sure if I want to have children. I'm not sure if I'll get married. I know who I will marry. I'm interesting. I'm a good liar. People enjoy talking to me. When I'm not zoning out that is. Or maybe they say they like talking to me precisely because I zone out... I annoy people from time to time. Kasi minsan maingay at taklesa ako. -- HAHA AKO RIN! I'm a born leader. I'm a born leader but shouldn't lead. I enjoy felching. I have a foot fetish. I have a shoe fetish. I watch "Sex and the City." I used to. A little of it. I don't think Sarah Jessica Parker is pretty. I wanna be J.Lo. I cut myself. I've cut myself. A lot of times. By accident. Hehe. I hate people who pretend to be suicidal. I hate popular people. I think cheerleading is a sport. I'm photogenic. I live in Chucks. Any pair of sneakers, actually. I think graffiti is art. I have dated a criminal. I have been cheated on. Define cheating. I have cheated on someone. I have a temper. I easily get frustrated but I rarely get angry. I scare myself when I'm angry. I like playgrounds. So very very much. I dance in the rain. I'm obsessed with Shakespeare. I have tanlines. They're gone now. I wanna have them back soon! My favourite color is pink. My favourite color is black I would classify myself as emo. HAHA at times I am! I'm musically inclined. I like listening to music I like music-blasting cars. Thongs are comfortable. I like flip-flops. I know what monogamy is... ...and I believe in it. I wanna be a social worker when I grow up. I have sibling/s. My sibling/s annoy me. I think "South Park" is funny I believe in LOVE And I tag all of you!

* i'm starting to get used to not having internet at home. i rarely miss it now. which is a good thing -- i get to paint and write more. :D * i'm going to be a wedding sponsor! wheeee~! a good friend is getting married this october and i can't wait! i'm playing for the happy couple too so double wheee~! * sj and jess visited me while i was sick at home last saturday. hehe, mukha akong putok, pero ok lang. (di bale, next week iinstall na yung kitchen counter!) * after a coupla hospital visits (and needle pricks, yeow), i find out that i have *ehem* upper respiratory tract bacterial infection. as of late, i've very low resistance to sickness, and an almost borderline white blood cell count. thus i walk around with a gauze mask since anything can trigger an allergic reaction. can't move much either or i'll get fever. but would that stop me? NOOOOOOOOOO! because... * ...TODAY IS CHERYL'S 18th BIRHTDAY! WHOOPDEEDOO! (gad i'm old)

I remember warm afternoons with my grandfather. I would stay with him in his room and watch him type thousands and thousands of legal documents. He was a lawyer, and a good one at that. He once threw a law book at a judge and got suspended from court. I remember the scent of those days with him; it was the smell of wood and paper, mixed with crisp collared shirts and old tennis balls. He used to make little songs for me -- my favorite was "Bubbles" -- and we would both sing and sing while I blew bubbles from my little Zesto straw, until the sun set and we got slightly hoarse. I've had good memories with him. His passing was my first experience of death. I was in grade school then, a little kid watching herself in the mirror. When I suddenly heard my grandmother's cry from my grandfather's room I saw my eyes widen -- I knew what it meant and yet I couldn't bring myself to scream. The days that followed melted into one another. I felt as if I was floating somewhere between sleep and waking. Nothing made sense. It was painful, and I didn't know how to handle pain. When he died, he left a certain void in me that hasn't really been filled in. And then, years later as we were cleaning the house, my mom handed me a piece of paper. "I think this is for you."
All of a sudden I felt all those well-missed afternoons crash into me with such intensity that I lost my breath. I could almost see sunbeams dancing on the wooden floor panels, smell the old books and the and old tennis balls scattered about, hear the clickity-clack of the bulky typewriter and the sound of an old, old voice singing to me about bubbles, and breezes, and beauty. I think I cried then. I never asked about his inheritance. I never really cared for it. This yellowed sheet of paper is all that matters. This is his legacy to me. So are all those bright afternoons with him so very long ago that I'll always, always remember.
* * *
For Daddy I don't really know how long it's been, but it's been too long. I miss you.
* * *

one of our supervisors has the unplugged version of "beautiful disaster" by kelly clarkson. yeah yeah, so i'm an american idol groupie but hell, the lyrics made me sniffle! He drowns in his dreams An exquisite extreme, I know He's as damned as he seems And more heaven than a heart could hold If I tried to save him My whole world could cave in It just ain't right, it just ain't right Oh and I don't know I don't know what he's after But he's so beautiful Such a beautiful disaster And if I could hold on Through the tears and the laughter Would it be beautiful Or just a beautiful disaster His magic and myth As strong as what I believe A tragedy with More damage than a soul should see And do I try to change him So hard not to blame him Hold on tight, hold on tight Oh 'cause I don't know I don't know what he's after But he's so beautiful Such a beautiful disaster And if I could hold on Through the tears and the laughter Would it be beautiful Or just a beautiful disaster I'm longing for love and the logical But he's only happy, hysterical I'm waiting for some kind of a miracle Waiting so long So long He's soft to the touch But frayed at the end, he breaks He's never enough And still he's more than I can take Oh 'cause I don't know Don't know what he's after But he's so beautiful Such a beautiful disaster And if I could hold on Through the tears and the laughter Would it be beautiful Or just a beautiful disaster He's beautiful Such a beautiful disaster Oh oh...beautiful Oh oh...beautiful disaster i think at some point, every girl has met her beautiful disaster.

a normal conversation in the owen residence: ma: ARGH! bakit madami nanaman kayo dito? cheryl: sinong kausap mo? ma: yung mga langgam. cheryl: tingnan mo ng maigi, nakangiti sila sa yo. ma: . . . di ko makita eh. masyadong maliit. and you people wonder why i'm this weird?
* * *
happy father's day to my dad
 you once wanted to be a doctor, now you're selling beer. can't get any cooler than that. i love you papa!
nyak~! a quick hi and how are you are all i can manage for now. still got no pc in the new house. HUWAH! ilang buwan na akong walang matinong internet time! oh dear. we have to leave now. ach. ja~!

The recent tropical storm signaled the closing of summer for me. I would've wanted the warm sun and clear skies to last longer, but oh I took what I got and it had been great. laguna

My dad took us with him to his department outing in a resort in Laguna. Actually, there wasn't really much to see, except for the beautiful misty slopes of Mt. Makiling. While my dad played poker with his officemates (he looked funny, actually -- parang laging lugi), Cheryl and I soaked in the pool before hopping in the jacuzzi. Then we spent the whole day sleeping.
subic

This was the trip my officemates and I took just to get away from work. 0_o We didn't really get to swim since the sea was plankton-infested and it was effing itchy. But the sea breeze was great and the sun was high and warm and it felt really good just to lie back on the sand underneath a coconut tree. ^_^ After balking at the P4,000+ price tag of a "dolphin encounter" in Sea World, we wandered aimlessly looking for a place to eat until we ended up at Padi's Point. It was quite a dinner experience, what with watching a geriatric American dancing with a Filipina who obviously had an after-hours kind of profession. It was sad, really. And a whole lot disturbing.

We woke up early the next morning and had a good breakfast at a divers' cafe. It was nice and cool, and we took a lot of pictures. ^_^ After the dropping by a PX shop and a National Bookstore (we couldn't help it -- we checked their stocks of Hallmark cards @_@), we went GO CARTING! We were so giddy waiting in line that we managed to piss of a group of Koreans racing before us (we were screaming and cheering and doing the wave -- when they got off it looked like they were cussing at us). Ten laps for P300 -- but after charming the administrators (hahaha!) they gave us 12 laps for the same price. Oho, sometimes it's great being a girl. We drove back to Manila to the tune of Eraserhead songs. Currently, we're making a music video of the whole trip, and it's sure to become blackmail-worthy.
palawan Wendi, my officemate, invited me out of impulse one day to come with her to Puerto Prinsesa, her hometown. Out of impulse too, I said yes. Sometimes, it pays not to think.

Palawan has got to be one of the most beautiful places in the planet. From the plane window, lush green lands greeted me, and it was so surreal I honestly felt dizzy (then again maybe I was just airsick ^_~). As soon as we landed we headed to Honda bay where Wendi's dad rented a bangka for all of us. We toured the islands, and each of them had their own kind of beauty to flaunt. It was great -- sharing lunch on one big banana leaf and snorkeling -- but the best part was the boat ride back to the port. I have never seen the sky so wide and the sea so great. Sitting there on the old fishing boat, I marveled at how the afternoon colors changed into so many shades; I've never seen such a beautiful sunset in my entire life. Everything was so beautiful, and it made me want to cry.

After hearing mass the next day, we headed to the balsahan in Iwahig, where we celebrated the birthday of Wendi's dad with lechon and alimango sa kamias at gata, among others. It was literally a feast, and I enjoyed eating by the stream watching kids jump into the clear waters. People told me that the place was enchanted, and as summer sunlight gently filtered through the trees, it seemed to me that it really was.

The same day, Mike brought us a few blocks from their house to a fishing village. He kept on telling us, "Ayos lang kayo ha, maglalakad tayo sa may dagat ng mga 30 minutes," and all the while we thought we were going to walk along the shore. Apparently, we were going to walk through the sea. Our destination was a sandbar far-off from the shore. The water we waded through was knee to thigh-high. We followed a worn path boarded by sea grass and jellyfish, taking with us our cameras, a bottle of lapad, and a labrador. It was tiring, and at some points scary, but hell, when we got there, it was BEAUTIFUL. The water was so clear, and starfish nonchalantly went about their business as we all sat in silence. In the end, we didn't get to down the lapad; we were all just there, sometimes sitting, sometimes wading, but almost always happily silent.
(Here's my favorite picture of the trip.)
(Yup! That's me!)
You know when sometimes, you're in the middle of something and then you just suddenly realize that wow, you can't ever forget that moment? During one evening as Mike took us around the city on his motorbike, I looked up at the sky and saw thousands of stars. The wind was threading through my hair and we kept on laughing about something and it just came to me -- "life is f*cking beautiful". I wasn't drunk; in fact I hadn't had a drop the whole day. Everything just crashed into me and I threw my head back and giggled like a toddler on sugarhigh. I'll always remember that moment -- speeding through the quiet Palawan streets on my first motorbike ride. One day, I'll do that again.
I'm still happily recovering from all the money I spent this summer, so I guess it means no more outings for me for the meantime. ^_^ Maybe sometime October, haha. One of our supervisors invited me to come with them to Sagada; maybe I'll take them up on that. Isn't the world a beautiful, beautiful place? ^_^

my social life is dying a slow and painful death.

me and my officemates have been working our asses off for a new product.  i don't know what it'll come out but i know that i'll totally laugh my head off when i see it in national bookstore outlets.

the only escape that we had was our trip to subic a couple of weeks ago.  the beach was beautiful but plankton-infested -- meaning you wade for a while before running out screeching and scratching all over the place.  wade, itch, run out.  wade, itch, run out.  we did that routine over and over again.  we were stubborn -- we weren't about to be bested by creatures at the lower end of the foodchain.

when we returned to manila, it was back to work.  yuck.

*pictures to come.  i haven't been back in project 8 in three weeks now and everything's uploaded in our pc there.

**more stories soon.  when i get internet access again.  my time's almost up in this cafe.
Guess who I saw in 168 last Thursday?

destabilization plots, rallying masses, and a whole lot of political hoo-hahs. ladies and gentlemen, the philippines. in spite of everything, i wouldn't want to be anywhere else.
* * *
every year, PLDT holds an art competition for the front cover design of their annual directory. my sister joined, and she got 6th place in their entire school. she's the only freshman who got in the top ten.
the title of her piece is "magtungo tayo sa pagkakaisa". i think it's high time we did.

valentine's day was quite... interesting. and undoubtedly nice. ^_^ oh oh, and i just have to share this -- my dad gave me a v-day gift. it's a model of the pink MMDA urinal with bayani fernando peeing in it. the box even has this tagline:
"urban street furniture. it may be smelly, but at least it's more dignified."
 i was laughing so hard all the way home i got side stitches.
* * *
last friday, my officemate ody and i performed for an office function. she sang and i played "angel" by sarah mclachlan. it was my very first time to be in front of an audience outside abelardo hall; moreover, it was my first time to have somebody singing beside me. truth be told, i am a bit uneasy about playing anything other than classical guitar -- probably because i am not really that good in the first place (after four years i still have a hard time reading notes and i almost can't read tabs), and because the training was made so that it doesn't entertain any other influence outside it (which is both a good thing and a bad thing). in any case, i think i did a good job accompanying ody, who's a really great singer. i got the chance to talk with the company president, a man who's got an ear for music. apparently, he's got a son who's a piano major in UP. we chatted for a while -- at least now he knows me. ^_~
* * *
i finally got to finish reading "memoirs of a geisha". it's a really great book, and the details and descriptions have the ability to render anyone with an imagination rather breathless. the movie... i have yet to see it. i am honestly not too keen about seeing chinese actresses play japanese roles -- what with the obvious issues between china and japan -- though i am sure that the producers have a valid explanation to that. anyway, i was browsing through pictures of geiko and maiko from the gion district in kyoto, when i found this really beautiful shot of a geiko bowing to the photographer.
as i read the arthur golden's book, this was how i imagined hatsumomo to be. isn't she beautiful?
my step-tito amer and my tita gigi came from the states to visit. they brought with them margo's last christmas gift. it's a necklace with a crucifix pendant. somehow, it's just so her.

i have a killer headache. i actually want to throw up right now. anyway, my notorious officemate's once again in action: K.B: libre ko kayo cafe lupe. pero ngayong gabi lang, bukas wala na. Me: Awww... di kami pwede tonight. PWET: Charlene, tayo na lang, date na lang tayo. Me: NEKNEK MO. KB: HAHAHA~! BARADO! oh, and recently, he wiggled my big toe while singing, "this little piggy went to the market..." i was holding an open cutter then. i almost committed murder. in spite of everything, i'm still trying to be nice to him. nagbabagong-buhay na ako ngayon. but that doesn't mean i like being within a ten-meter radius of him. sadly, it's just something that i have to live with. it is an excercise in patience, and patience is in my list of new year's resolutions. ...ugh.

Name five of life's simple pleasures that you like most, then pick five people to do the same. Try to be original and creative and not to use things that someone else has already used.

1. wearing dresses.
2. skipping when i feel like it, may it be in a public place or at home.  (this goes hand-and-hand with jumping over sprinklers and walking barefoot on grass.)
3. listening to the music of a solo instrument.  cellos especially.  they make me cry.
4. a cup of coffee/tea/chocolate in a nice cozy place during rainy days.  (i'll curl up in a nice chair and wiggle my toes and blow on my drink and wait until the fog on my glasses disappear. ^_^)
5. seeing constellations on really clear nights.  oh and seeing rainbows too.  rainbows are kinda rare nowadays.

Ten Top Trivia Tips about Charlene Owen!

  1. Devoid of her cells and proteins, Charlene Owen has the same chemical makeup as sea water.
  2. Charlene Owen can clean her ears with her tongue, which is over thirty-nine inches long.
  3. Louisa May Alcott, author of 'Little Charlene Owen', hated Charlene Owen and only wrote the book at her publisher's request.
  4. The water in oceans is four times less salty than the water in Charlene Owen.
  5. Over 46,000 pieces of Charlene Owen float on every square mile of ocean.
  6. On stone temples in southern India, there are more than 30 million carved images of Charlene Owen.
  7. White chocolate isn't technically chocolate, because it doesn't contain Charlene Owen.
  8. The book of Esther in the Bible is the only book which does not mention Charlene Owen.
  9. Peanuts and Charlene Owen are beans.
  10. Charlene Owenolatry is the mindless worship of Charlene Owen.

sweet dreams~!
my boss gave each of the girls a spritzer of "pillow perfume" for christmas. the innocent-looking liquid apparently gives one "a good night's sleep and sweet dreams". wendi, my groupmate, gave it a try and told us the next day that she did have a nice dream though she couldn't remember what it was about. tyrene and i agreed to do the same that evening. the next morning she said "gumana siya~!". apparently, she dreamt about walking in intramuros on a nice, cool morning, and she felt really happy. "ang ganda ng gising ko! ikaw, gumana ba sa yo?" in fact, my friends, it did. more than i would have expected it to. i dreamt i was looking for rianne (another officemate) in this strange white place. a door materialized in front of me, and i knocked. it took a while before it opened but when it did, i reeled back in surprise. standing with one hand on the knob was this tall, handsome asian guy with nice pecs wearing nothing but a white towel around his waist. i actually remember trying to hide a silly smile when he let me in. he was hot. HOT. i gingerly stepped inside and i was floored by dozens of tall, handsome asian guys with nice pecs in those goddamn white towels. then, as i was sinfully frolicking towards rain (that korean guy from "full house"), there was igiboo. i don't know why the heck she was in my dream but there was igiboo. she gave me a broad smile (not unlike that of a mama-san's) and while motioning earnestly towards those half-naked men, she said, "CHARLENE! WELCOME! yes, yes do come in! do come in!" and then i woke up. tyrene was laughing hysterically by the time i finished talking. later that afternoon, we told our boss about it and she said, "hey wait a minute, i should get my own bottle too!" am i repressed? wait, don't answer that.
* * *
suitors
last christmas, as in every family occasion, i was asked -- "charlene? may boyfriend ka na ba?" i said "no", and as per tradition, my dad went on with his famous lecture. "if you're going to have a boyfriend, make sure that he treats you properly. he must be able to feed you, and take care of you, and give you a house..." around this point my mom cut him short. "we aren't talking about a husband, dear. we're talking about a boyfriend." "it doesn't matter." my dad is very stubborn when it comes to my love life. "ayoko ng panay pa-pogi lang. pa-pogi ng pa-pogi wala namang natapos o napag-aralan! i want him to be able to provide for you. i don't want just anybody out there. remember that ha? remember that." since it was christmas, my grandma was with us. she had been nodding all throughout my dad's lecture, and with half-lidded eyes and nose held high she said, "your daddy's right. you must get a capable boyfriend. wala pang nagkakamali sa familia natin." every time she uses that f-word, i feel like i'm the daughter of some haciendero in a cheesy afternoon soap, who wouldn't get her inheritance if she doesn't marry a rich man of noble birth (who by some accident was switched with a poor kid back in the hospital where he was born thus making him live a hard life full of self-made misery and stupid martyrdom). that evening, i lay awake on my bed for about an hour or so. i kept on thinking, "what if i don't want to marry the proverbial corporate dude? what if i don't want a posh condo in makati? what if i want to raise my family in a quaint little house in italy? what if i want to marry an italian cheese maker?!" thus began the infamous list of charlene's probable suitors. technically, it's a list of men with different nationalities and cute jobs and which interest me. that sheet of paper made it around the creatives department and with the help of my officemates, i got around 60 probable (imaginary) suitors and counting. here are a few from the list. if you want to add a suitor, place your suggestion on the comments section. it will be very much appreciated. charlene's list of probable suitors italian cheese maker italian wine taster transylvanian vampire hunter mexican mariachi (who looks like antonio banderas and bathes everyday and has a grime-free nape) british lost boy texan cowboy (who bathes everyday and has a grime-free nape) argentinian gaucho (who bathes... you know the drill) russian violinist filipino pearl diver filipino maglalatik japanese kabuki actor arabian thief (with a magic lamp) chinese wu-shu master japanese kendo master british butt/elbow-double of jude law scottish kilt designer american nat geo photographer french nose (perfumer) german beermaster italian violin-maker in the tradition of stradivarius half-indian half-californian crime fighter (aka "zorro") latino poet tibetan sherpa trainer panamanian tailor vietnamese hair-rebonder (from beverly hills) english choirboy bruneian heir to the throne latino salsa/tango dancer japanese geisha wardrobe assistant peruvian llama raiser ...ah...but an excerpt. it's a long list. :D anybody care to add to it?
* * *

hello friends! it's been a while since i posted. ^_^ a lot has happened since last year, but it'll be too much to post everything. all's good though, in spite of the momentary bouts of psychological hoo-hahs. i don't think i'll be able to post as much anymore, since i wouldn't have access to the internet most of the time. (it's a long story, but if you want to know the details just ask me the next time we see each other.) hopefully, that would be remedied soon, since i do miss them clickity keyboard sounds at 1 in the morning. anyway, as much as it's the start of the new year -- well a couple of weeks since the start of the new year -- i think it would be proper to write my resolutions. they're simple enough, so that it's possible for me to really do them. charlene's happy new year list i will... ... study capoeira. or at least enroll in a gym since the 4:00 classes in ateneo would conflict with my 4:30 guitar classes in UP. ...write more. though i have been writing (stuff that i won't be posting but hopefully printing), i think i should practice my style more (if i actually have any). i read through my stories and i think i'm becoming too wordy. if mrs. fernandez were still alive, she would check my papers and return them bleeding. ...learn to control my temper. i found myself shrieking like a banshee last week in divisoria due to an annoying dumb ass tindera. my officemates left me, and i was hella embarrassed. ...watch all the dvds that my friends lent me. sheps. andami nito. ...finish my drawings, especially gio's request. (see? i didn't forget about that. sorry it's taking months.) ...spend more time with my friends. ...go out of the country. the world is just too big not to explore! hm. the list looks boring but at least my resolutions are realistic. ^_^ check on me again this time next year, and i'll give you a bar of chocolate for every resolution that i didn't get to follow through. ^_~ hopefully i'll get to post sooner than next saturday. toodles~!

ang mahal ng e-vat. ang mahal-mahal ng e-vat.

(Disclaimer: This entry might not make sense to you, my dear reader, but I just needed to write it down.) No person in the entire planet who works in an office is ever safe from chismis. Not even if the said office happens to be owned by a company which plans and distributes an international greeting card line that promotes love, camaraderie, and respect. In other words, yours truly has been most honored to be chismised about. It wasn't much of a chismis -- then again it wasn't the full story. According to one of my groupmates (our department is divided into groups), this girl whom we'll call -- um -- Girlie (pardon the un-creativeness, half of my braincells are dead), reportedly expressed her extreme annoyance towards me to our other officemates. Apparently, Girlie thought that I was "papansin" and inis na inis na raw siya sa akin. Now, I am not one to easily believe such gossip. In spite of my experiences in the past, I still have faith in most people, and even if Girlie isn't somebody whom I would call a friend, I believe she's nice. Well, half the time she's nice. (Half the time she chooses to ignore my existence.) Anyway, the chismis made me think about certain things... (Enter cheesy flashback music.) In the past, in spite of all appearances, I was mighty insecure about myself. I was insecure about my looks, the way I dress, the way I talk, and even about the way I move. I wanted to belong. I wanted others to see that I was an okay girl, that I was acceptable. Moreover, I wanted to please everybody. I held their opinions in high regard, to the point that I was ignoring my inner voice. I was scared that people were talking about me behind my back, because I knew that if they saw something bad in me, they wouldn't want me anymore, and I wouldn't have "friends". Yes, I was very much afraid of chismis. Thus, I conformed. That went on until college. I tried very much to become a wallflower. During my freshman year I wore nothing but sleeved shirts, baggy pants and rubber shoes. My hair was long and most of the time unkept. I really didn't want the attention. And then came my mom who told me that no matter what I do -- even if I were to stand really still and stop breathing -- I would always draw attention, whether or not for good or ill. It was just my personality. I exude this (and I quote) "vibe" when I enter a room that it's impossible not to notice that I'm there, even if I'm just sitting in one sorry corner. That's according to her. Later on, I started believing her. It's hard to explain but couldn't be sneaky even if I died trying. So basically, all that wallflowering drama was for naught. I attracted attention whether I was noisy or silent. But then it was more than just "the vibe". In my opinion, there is another, more physical factor as to why I attract attention: Boobs. Yes, I am well-endowed. I am chest-fully blessed. Maganda ang hinaharap ko. I have big boobs. I've had my fair share of men, women, and gays looking down there instead of up here. For some reason, they all found my breasts rather fascinating, in spite of the fact that they have their own. Moreover, I've had thousands of boob jokes thrown my way (and yeah, most of them are funny). I've learned to live with all that. And yes, I love my breasts, even if they do attract undue attention, and even if they give some people the impression that I'm nothing but an airhead. Anyway -- As much as I learned living with big boobs (yes, you get used to it), I learned how to live with "the vibe". It has worked for my good as much as it has worked for my ruin. I've had people telling me that I am doggone annoying even if I don't even remember doing anything. I remember some people telling me that I'm a flirt, while others just thought that I'm plain kulang sa pansin and over-acting. Somebody from a few years ago even told me, "You walk funny". "What do you mean?" I asked. "You stride. You bounce." I never noticed that I did until then. "You don't like it?" "Not really. It attracts attention." And so silly little me tried to change the way I walk. Instead of "bouncing", I tried "shuffling". I shuffled for the longest time until I got tired of it and realized that hell, why the eff should I care if I bounce when I walk?! Why should I effing care if people don't like it? It's how I walk, and it gets me to where I'm going. Sorry if it ain't a pretty sight. From that time on, I realized that I didn't care anymore what other people said about me. The words KSP and OA just went in one ear and out the other. I started wearing tank tops and skirts. So what if they stared at my boobs? That's the closest they'd ever get to me anyway. So what if my heels clicked a little too loudly on the pavement? Remember -- I "stride" and "bounce" and I'm not about to change that. I've tried changing and conforming for so long, and I've gotted tired of it. I stopped listening to them, and I started listening to me. It was very liberating, finally learning how to be your own person. I will never again be slave to the opinions of others. The only opinions that matter to me are from those who truly accept me the way I am. Those are real friends -- not the ones who try to change you so that you'll conform to their standards. Yes, I'm still insecure about a lot of things, but now, I'm happy just being myself. I'm not perfect, but I'm me. Oh, Girlie's chismis? It doesn't really matter. I can't please everybody, and I'm not even gonna try to. Let them talk till kingdom come, I'll be happy living my own life. This is me. Take me or leave me. It's your choice. It's really that simple.

One evening after work, I stood with my officemates near an FX loading sign along C5. Beside me was a man in a white polo, and a good meter-and-a-half behind him was a suitcase, sitting in the middle of the sidewalk as if it were nobody's business. Being the scandalosa that I am, I blatantly pointed at it and said -- "Look! An abandoned suitcase! A bomb!" Almost everybody in our line looked. My friend Kate tugged at my sleeve, "Baka naman may may-ari niyan." "Eh bakit walang pumupulot?" I countered. "It looks like an effing bomb! That's scary shit!" The man in the white polo looked at me with an almost annoyed expression, while the rest of the group murmured in agreement and slowly edged away from the aforementioned object of apparent doom. It was really, REALLY suspicious. After all, it WAS sitting on the sidewalk of one of Metro Manila's main arteries. I was debating between kicking it to a corner or asking an MMDA officer to radio it in, when calmly, the man in the white polo picked it up and crossed the street. We stood there for a full minute, gaping after the suitcase's owner. "Ay," I muttered. "May may-ari nga." And we burst out laughing. We were still laughing when we boarded an FX, until another thought crossed my mind -- "AAAGH! TERRORIST!" But the FX had already started moving, and the man in the white polo was nowhere to be found.

i forced myself to slow down reading "Zorro" and i finally finished it a few days ago. it was effing good. isabel allende is officially one of my uber favorite authors. she's up there with banana yoshimoto, neil gaiman, nick joaquin, and the newest addition, alexandre dumas. i dunno how she does it, but she makes all the characters so darn believable. i am so in love with the way she writes! now Zorro is my current fictional crush. oh, him and edmond dantes. and cloud strife. ha. my officemate, seeing my facination with allende's work, lent me her copy of "Aphrodite - A Memoir Of The Senses". it's an entire book about seduction and food -- and that's totally generalizing it. she starts it with these words --
The fiftieth year of our life is like the last hour of dusk, when the sun has set and one turns naturally toward reflection. In my case, however, dusk incites me to sin, and perhaps for that reason, in my fiftieth year I find myself reflecting on my relationship with food and eroticism; the weakness of the flesh that most tempt me are not, alas, those I have practiced most...
(hehehe... true though. maybe we don't "sin" too often. maybe sometimes, to sin is to find what is godly... i hope i won't wait for my fiftieth year to sin a hell lot! Xp) i love her way with words. she even has this beautiful photo of herself on the backcover --
that is just so darn NICE! i want to have a photo of me that's something like that -- naughty, but very artistically done. anyway, i shall go back to my reading now. (isabel you're my idol! *hearts!*)

here's a couple of text conversations with my mother: #1 ma: SAAN KA NA? me: white plains na ma: saan ka ibababa, sa mrt station? me: hindi, bahay na daw. ma: okei, tenkyu kami hapi beerday. :) that was WEIRD. for some odd reason, she sounded like ms jess. and i don't even know where the "hapi beerday" came from. #2 me: i'm home na. :) ma: omigosh! praise the lord! me: BLEH. ma: PPTHTHTH okay, that was the first time she ever texted me with an "omigosh". and what in the world is a "PPTHTHTH"? my mother is funny.

I finally opened my yearbook.  I was a bit apprehensive to do so at first due to certain issues which I wrote about way back, but when I browsed through the pages, I realized that in the end, I did have a good time in college.  I met great people too, and seeing their faces as they were a couple of years ago made me feel a tad bit nostalgic.  I see some of them often, but I only hear stories about most.  

I miss those whom I rarely have time to be with.  Reading through the yearbook made memories come back to me like scenes from an old movie.


<font color="#800080">Chad</font> -- I remember sitting on the library steps one afternoon during my last semester.  I was a total emotional wreck then.  I didn't really want to be alone, so I texted Chad and asked him where he was.  Apparently he just got back to his dorm across Katipunan, but when he sensed that I wasn't doing pretty well, he came back to school, walked up the lib steps, and sat with me.  We didn't say much to each other -- he just sat with me.  And that was a lot.

<font color="#800080">Mia</font> -- I remember a lot of moments with Mia, but one of the clearest was of that night we sped through Katipunan screaming our heads off in her car.  Life was unfair, and all we could do was to rage against it with fists to the air and mouths wide open.  It felt so damn great.  

<font color="#800080">Mihk</font> -- I remember singing "Be Our Guest" with him.  There was also his Naruto jacket and his Naruto pose.  And then there were those simple, silly conversations within which he would manage to slip in little by little the meaning of life.  I don't know where he got all his wisdom, as much as I don't know where he got his copy of "Jesus Christ Vampire Hunter".

<font color="#800080">Jean</font> -- I remember our conversations along an empty SEC walkway.  She told me that when she died, she wanted them to play Imago's "Alay".  I answered that I wanted Cookie Chua's "Paglisan", and then I said yeah, "Alay" too.  We talked about climbing trees and playing shadows, and I remember feeling the afternoon breeze against my skin and seeing the Acasia branches slightly swaying.

<font color="#800080">Cris</font> -- I remember rainy days in Starbucks Katipunan, and all those stories about lovers who have come and gone.  I remember her exclaiming "What a stupid ass!" before ranting about the aforementioned -- er -- ass.  Back then I could only shake my head and laugh.  But that's Cris.  She was one of the few people who gave me strength during rough times, and I never even got to thank her.  Well, Cris -- thank you.

<font color="#800080">Jon Moll</font> -- He was a batch higher, but it didn't really matter.  I remember us shooting for his thesis film -- "Kita-kits".  I remember sitting on the back of Dan's old pick up in front of his house, while the group talked about the rushes and how to get home.  I remember looking up at the night sky and seeing stars.  I didn't know there were a lot of stars in Paranaque.  I remember thinking, "Life couldn't be better than this."


Sometimes I wonder if I'll ever share such moments with these people again.  We live different lives now, and we bother about different things... Then I realize that knowing them and having the chance to be with them in the four most enjoyable years of my life is more than enough.  

In any case, I know we'll bumping into each other soon.  We're still friends, after all.  In my book, we'll always be.

i told myself that i will NOT buy any more books after i got a copy of "right words a the right time" which cost me more than a thousand pesos. but since i had to wait for my dad to finish his meeting and i had nothing else to do in megamall today, i went to powerbooks. eff that place! i just ALWAYS have to buy something everytime i'm there. i got me "the count of monte cristo" by alexandre dumas. not only that, i also bought sarah mclachlan's "mirrorball" and the pepe smith's new album "idiosycrasies". that's easily another thousand out my wallet. gad. i have to learn self-control. masamang bisyo na to.
